body.p: By Emma Thomasson

BERLIN, Sept 23 (Reuters) - German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder, whose opposition to a U.S. war with Iraq helped him win re-election, began mending ties on Monday by announcing the departure of a controversial minister.
However, he gave no sign that all would now be harmony with Germany's NATO ally, insisting on his right to differences of opinion.

Schroeder's first move was to announce that Herta Daeubler-Gmelin, the justice minister who last week allegedly said Bush's desire to distract from domestic politics with war recalled Hitler's methods, would not be in his new cabinet.
Although she denied making the comparison, Schroeder told a news conference she had asked not to be considered.
But he also said he would not change his stance on Iraq -- which has brought rebukes from Washington -- and rejected suggestions that his position had damaged transatlantic ties.
"The basis of the relationship between Germany and the United States is so secure that the fears that were played up during the election campaign are unfounded," he said.
"Between friends, there can be factual differences but they should not be personalised, particularly between close allies."

Werner Weidenfeld, head of the Centre for Applied Policy Research in Munich, said Schroeder could not quickly make a complete about-turn on Iraq without alienating the large number of voters he won over with his anti-war rhetoric.
"It will not be easy to repair the badly damaged relationship with the U.S. government," Weidenfeld said.
POISONED ATMOSPHERE

Germany will be looking to see whether U.S. President George W. Bush offers Schroeder anything more than ritual congratulations, and how long it is before Schroeder gets a by-now traditional post-election invitation to the White House.
Germany is expected to offer to relieve pressure on U.S. and British forces -- the likely leaders of any attack on Iraq -- by offering to take a bigger role in Afghan peacekeeping.
But that may not be enough to quickly improve an atmosphere that U.S. National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice said had been poisoned by Germany's comments on Iraq.
U.S. Defence Secretary Donald Rumsfeld suggested he would avoid his German counterpart at a NATO meeting on Tuesday.
Germany's DIHK chambers of commerce and industry said Berlin must mend ties or risk damage to its economic interests.
Schroeder's trump card may be Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, believed to have a solid reputation in Washington.

Fischer, of the Greens party, said Germany would never forget that it had the Americans to thank for freeing them from Nazi dictatorship and helping bring about German unification after long years of support through the Cold War.
"America is a guarantor of peace and security," he said. "The United States is our most important partner and we want to further develop the traditionally good path of our relations."
Karsten Voigt, Schroeder's adviser on U.S. affairs, told ARD television the chancellor, too, would have to build bridges.

"He must make clear that we are agreed on the goal that (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein cannot be allowed to possess weapons of mass destruction, and that despite all differences...it is not the policies of the Americans that is the problem but the behaviour of Saddam Hussein," he said.
SOFTER LINE?

German diplomats have suggested Schroeder's opposition to war against Iraq may ease if Saddam fails to cooperate fully with U.N.-mandated arms inspections or is proved to have weapons of mass destruction -- Washington's central grievance.
"The experienced foreign policy experts will hopefully take over the driving seat again now the election campaign is over," said Bernhard May of the German Council on Foreign Relations.
May urged Schroeder to write to Bush explaining his position said predicted the chancellor would probably fall into line if the U.N. Security Council agreed a tough new resolution on Iraq.
Voigt said German forces were likely to free up U.S. and British forces for Iraq by taking on more responsibility in the Balkans and Afghanistan.

Defence Minister Peter Struck has suggested a German-Dutch command could take over the leadership of the international peacekeeping force in Afghanistan when Turkey's mandate expires at the end of the year, and increase its troop contingent.

He is expected to discuss the plan with his Dutch counterpart at a meeting of NATO defence ministers in Warsaw on Tuesday and said he would also speak to his U.S. opposite number Rumsfeld, even if the American had said he did not know Struck.
"Relations are politically difficult at the moment, but they will improve," Struck said on Sunday. (With additional reporting by Markus Krah)
